p.em: These exercises address graphing sinusoidal curves and the graphs of other trigonometric functions.

statement.p: Practice drawing the graph of y = \sin (\theta), y = \cos (\theta), and \tan(\theta) by considering the geometry of the unit circle.

hint.p: Remember that cosine is the x-coordinate and sine is the y-coordinate of the point on the unit circle determined by \theta. Tangent is the slope of the terminal ray.

statement.p: Sketch the graphs of y = - 2 \cos (\theta), y = \cos(\theta)-2, y = \cos(2\theta), and y = \cos(\theta/2).

ul.li: y=-2\cos\theta is the graph of cosine reflected over the horizontal axis and stretched vertically by a factor of 2 to give an amplitude of 2.
y=\cos\theta-2 is the graph of cosine translated down 2 units
y=\cos(2\theta) is the graph of cosine stretched horizontally by a factor of 1/2 resulting in a period of \pi.
y=\cos(\theta/2) is the graph of cosine stretched horizontally by a factor of 2 resulting in a period of 4\pi.

statement.p: Sketch one period of y=2\sin\left(3t-\frac{\pi}{4}\right). Identify the amplitude, period, and phase shift.

hint.p: First solve 3t-\frac{\pi}{4} = 0 and 3t-\frac{\pi}{4} = 2\pi for t to find where one period begins and ends, respectively.

solution.p:
To find where a period begins, solve
3t - \frac{\pi}{4} = 0 \Rightarrow t = \frac{\pi}{12}.
To find where this same period ends, solve
3t - \frac{\pi}{4} = 2\pi \Rightarrow t = \frac{3\pi}{4}.
We can plot this one period
to see that its the graph of sine shifted \pi/12 units to the right with a period of 3\pi/4 - \pi/12= 2\pi/3 and an amplitude of 2.

hint.p: First solve 2\left(t+\frac{\pi}{6}\right) = 0 and 2\left(t+\frac{\pi}{6}\right) = 2\pi for t to find where one period begins and ends, respectively.

solution.p:
To find where a period begins, solve
2\left(t+\frac{\pi}{6}\right) = 0 \Rightarrow t = -\pi/6.
To find where this same period ends, solve
2\left(t+\frac{\pi}{6}\right) = 2\pi \Rightarrow t = 5\pi/6.
We can plot this one period
to see that its the graph of cosine reflected over the t-axis, shifted \pi/6 units to the left with a period of 5\pi/6 - (-\pi/6)= \pi and an amplitude of 1. the peak occurs at the midpoint of (5\pi/6 + (-\pi/6))/2 = \pi/3.

statement.p: Sketch one period of y = \tan(2x). Label the vertical asymptotes and at least three points on the graph for scale.

solution.p: The graph of y = \tan \theta has asymptotes where \theta = \pm \pi/2. So if 2x = \pm \pi/2 \Rightarrow x = \pm \pi/4 we will see asymptotes on y = \tan(2x). This means the period shrinks to \pi/2.

statement.p: Use the graph of y = \sin(\theta) to help you sketch the graph of its reciprocal y = \csc(\theta).
